author: harithk
content:
hey all, 

etherscan wants to show the % size of a block compared to its target - eg showing 200% when gas limit is 15,000,000 and gas used is 30,000,000 like we currently do here

will the gaslimit returned by eth_getblock be the canonical 'target' of a given block under 1559 that we can simply use?

author: harithk
content: or will doing that be circular reasoning

author: sky.cactus
content: Gas limit is 30M in that example.

author: sky.cactus
content: Gas target is half that.

author: harithk
content:
ok so **gasLimit** from eth_getblock will be the amount actually used within the block. is there any way we can tell that it is 200/150/100/50% of the current target? is that by looking at trend from previous blocks?

and if so what will **gasUsed** represent?

author: sky.cactus
content: `gasLimit` is the gas limit for the block.  `gasUsed` is how much gas was actually used in the block.

author: sky.cactus
content: If `gasUsed > gasLimit`, the block is invalid.

author: sky.cactus
content: `gasTarget = gasLimit / 2`.

author: enigmatic331
content:
Any chance you might know if there is a jsonrpc field in the pipeline differentiating between gaslimit and gastarget, or would it be good enough to take the current gasLimit response * 2?

(i.e. then we will show GasLimit: 30M and GasTarget: 15M for the above example)

author: sky.cactus
content: `gasLimit / 2` is the `gasTarget` as of London.

author: sky.cactus
content: Prior to London, there is no such thing as a `gasTarget`.

author: patricio.palladino
content:
Does anyone have info about how geth sorts transactions (by default) when 1559 is activated? 

I'm trying to understand if sorting by `maxPriorityFeePerGas` is a sensible thing to do in Hardhat.

author: lightclient
content: <@!453707755765760021> in the block or tx pool?

author: patricio.palladino
content: within a block

author: lightclient
content: generally sorted by `effectiveMinerFee`

author: lightclient
content: so `min(tx.tip, feeCap - baseFee)`

author: patricio.palladino
content: ah, makes sense, thanks

author: patricio.palladino
content: Does this mean that geth sort its mempool after each block? Because the `baseFee` changes

author: lightclient
content: Miners have always resorted the includible transactions each block. After 1559, non-mining nodes will also now sort a fixed portion of their pending txs. Check out the write up linked in the PR for more info: https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/pull/22898

author: patricio.palladino
content: great! thank you

content: looks like RPC impls currently deviate slightly from the spec - this PR would bring the spec in alignment: https://github.com/ethereum/eth1.0-specs/pull/221
